title: Deterministic computation of the characteristic polynomial in the time of matrix multiplication

sections.new tools, and ensuring reduced form in:
When outlining the approach of our determinant algorithm via the identity in
Eq. 1, we implicitly assumed that the
matrices used as input in recursive calls, i.e. 𝐀1subscript𝐀1\mathbf{{A}}_{1} and 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2}
and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{{B}}, do satisfy the input requirement of row reducedness: this is
not necessarily the case, even if starting from a reduced matrix 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}}. Concerning 𝐀1subscript𝐀1\mathbf{{A}}_{1}, one may locate such a reduced submatrix of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}}
and then permute rows and columns of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} (which only affects the sign of
det(𝐀)𝐀\det(\mathbf{{A}})) to make this submatrix become the leading
principal submatrix 𝐀1subscript𝐀1\mathbf{{A}}_{1}. This is a classical operation on reduced
matrices which suggests using a form slightly stronger than reduced form called
weak Popov form [ref]36 (see Section 2.4). Assuming
that 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} has this form ensures that its leading principal submatrix
𝐀1subscript𝐀1\mathbf{{A}}_{1} has it as well. This assumption is acceptable in terms of
complexity since one can transform a reduced 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} into a weak Popov
𝐏𝐏\mathbf{{P}} by means of fast linear algebra in a cost negligible compared to
our target [42, Sec. 3]; note that 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} and 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{{P}} have
the same determinant up to an easily found constant (see
Algorithm 1). Next, the cases of 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2} and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{{B}} are strongly linked. First, we
will not discuss 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2} but the whole kernel basis [𝐊1​𝐊2]delimited-[]subscript𝐊1subscript𝐊2[\mathbf{{K}}_{1}\;\;\mathbf{{K}}_{2}]. The fastest known algorithm for computing such a basis is that of
, and for best efficiency it outputs a matrix in shifted
reduced form, which is a generalization of reducedness involving degree weights
given by a tuple 𝒔∈ℤm𝒔superscriptℤ𝑚\boldsymbol{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{m} called a shift (see
Sections 2.3 and 2.4 for definitions); the non-shifted
case is for 𝒔=𝟎𝒔0\boldsymbol{s}=\mathbf{0}. As in the determinant algorithm of
[ref]32, here the shift for [𝐊1​𝐊2]delimited-[]subscript𝐊1subscript𝐊2[\mathbf{{K}}_{1}\;\;\mathbf{{K}}_{2}] is taken as
the list of row degrees of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}}, denoted by 𝒔=rdeg​(𝐀)𝒔rdeg𝐀\boldsymbol{s}=\mathrm{rdeg}(\mathbf{{A}}); for
the characteristic matrix one has 𝒔=(1,…,1)𝒔1…1\boldsymbol{s}=(1,\ldots,1) but non-uniform
shifts may arise in recursive calls. We want [𝐊1​𝐊2]delimited-[]subscript𝐊1subscript𝐊2[\mathbf{{K}}_{1}\;\;\mathbf{{K}}_{2}] to
be not only 𝒔𝒔\boldsymbol{s}-reduced, but in 𝒔𝒔\boldsymbol{s}-weak Popov form: a direct
consequence is that 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{{B}} is in weak Popov form, and is thus suitable
input for a recursive call. To obtain [𝐊1​𝐊2]delimited-[]subscript𝐊1subscript𝐊2[\mathbf{{K}}_{1}\;\;\mathbf{{K}}_{2}] we use the kernel basis algorithm of
 and transform its output into 𝒔𝒔\boldsymbol{s}-weak Popov form. A
minor issue is that the fastest known algorithm for such transformations was
written in [42, Sec. 3] for non-shifted forms; yet it easily
extends to shifted forms as we show in Section 4,
obtaining the next result. There is an algorithm ReducedToWeakPopov which takes as input a
matrix 𝐀∈𝕂​[x]m×n𝐀𝕂superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥𝑚𝑛\mathbf{{A}}\in\mathbb{K}[x]^{m\times n} with m≤n𝑚𝑛m\leq n and a shift
𝐬∈ℤn𝐬superscriptℤ𝑛\boldsymbol{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{n} such that 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} is in 𝐬𝐬\boldsymbol{s}-reduced form,
and returns an 𝐬𝐬\boldsymbol{s}-weak Popov form of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} using
O​(mω−2​n​D+mω−1​n)𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔2𝑛𝐷superscript𝑚𝜔1𝑛\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega-2}nD+m^{\omega-1}n\right)}{O(m^{\omega-2}nD+m^{\omega-1}n)}{O(m^{\omega-2}nD+m^{\omega-1}n)}{O(m^{\omega-2}nD+m^{\omega-1}n)} operations
in 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}, where D=|rdeg𝐬​(𝐀)|−m⋅min⁡(𝐬)𝐷subscriptrdeg𝐬𝐀⋅𝑚𝐬D=|\mathrm{rdeg}_{{\boldsymbol{s}}}(\mathbf{{A}})|-m\cdot\min(\boldsymbol{s}). Here, following usual notation recalled in
Section 2.1, |rdeg𝒔​(𝐀)|subscriptrdeg𝒔𝐀|\mathrm{rdeg}_{{\boldsymbol{s}}}(\mathbf{{A}})| is the sum of
the 𝒔𝒔\boldsymbol{s}-degrees of the rows of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}}. This result extends
[42, Thm. 13] since for 𝒔=𝟎𝒔0\boldsymbol{s}=\mathbf{0} the quantity
D𝐷D is the sum of the row degrees of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} and in particular
D≤m​deg⁡(𝐀)𝐷𝑚degree𝐀D\leq m\deg(\mathbf{{A}}), leading to the cost bound
O​(mω−1​n​deg⁡(𝐀))𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔1𝑛degree𝐀\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega-1}n\deg(\mathbf{{A}})\right)}{O(m^{\omega-1}n\deg(\mathbf{{A}}))}{O(m^{\omega-1}n\deg(\mathbf{{A}}))}{O(m^{\omega-1}n\deg(\mathbf{{A}}))}. To summarize, at this stage we have outlined how to ensure, without exceeding
our target cost bound, that 𝐀1subscript𝐀1\mathbf{{A}}_{1} and 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{{B}} are valid input for
recursive calls, i.e. are in weak Popov form. Having det(𝐀1)subscript𝐀1\det(\mathbf{{A}}_{1}) and
det(𝐁)𝐁\det(\mathbf{{B}}), it remains to find det(𝐊2)subscript𝐊2\det(\mathbf{{K}}_{2}) and then the sought
det(𝐀)𝐀\det(\mathbf{{A}}) follows. We noted that, to ensure the form of 𝐁𝐁\mathbf{{B}} but
also for efficiency reasons, the kernel basis [𝐊1​𝐊2]delimited-[]subscript𝐊1subscript𝐊2[\mathbf{{K}}_{1}\;\;\mathbf{{K}}_{2}] is
computed in 𝒔𝒔\boldsymbol{s}-weak Popov form for the shift 𝒔=rdeg​(𝐀)𝒔rdeg𝐀\boldsymbol{s}=\mathrm{rdeg}(\mathbf{{A}}).
This causes the main difficulty related to our modification of the determinant
algorithm of [ref]32: 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2} is not valid input for a recursive
call since it is in 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v}-weak Popov form for some shift 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v},
a subtuple of 𝒔𝒔\boldsymbol{s} which is possibly nonzero. A first idea is to extend our approach to the shifted case, allowing recursive
calls with such a 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v}-reduced matrix: this is straightforward but
gives an inefficient algorithm. Indeed, along the recursion the shift drifts
away from its initial value and becomes arbitrarily large and unbalanced with
respect to the degrees of the input matrices of recursive calls. For example,
as mentioned above the sum of row degrees of the initial non-shifted
m×m𝑚𝑚m\times m matrix 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} is D=deg⁡(det(𝐀))𝐷degree𝐀D=\deg(\det(\mathbf{{A}})), whereas
for the 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v}-shifted (m/2)×(m/2)𝑚2𝑚2(m/2)\times(m/2) matrix 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2}
we only have the same bound D𝐷D instead of one related to
deg⁡(det(𝐊2))degreesubscript𝐊2\deg(\det(\mathbf{{K}}_{2})) itself, which is known to be at most D/2𝐷2D/2 in
our algorithm. This gap, here between D𝐷D and D/2𝐷2D/2, will only
grow as the algorithm goes down the tree of recursive calls, meaning that
degrees in matrices handled recursively are not sufficiently well controlled. Another idea is to compute a 𝟎0\mathbf{0}-reduced matrix which has the same
determinant as 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2}. Finding a 𝟎0\mathbf{0}-reduced form of
𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2} within our target cost seems to be a difficult problem. The best
known algorithms for general 𝟎0\mathbf{0}-reduction involve log⁡(m)𝑚\log(m)
factors, either explicitly  or implicitly  (in
the latter approach one starts by using the above-discussed triangularization
procedure of [ref]32 which we are modifying here to avoid
log⁡(m)𝑚\log(m) factors). More specific algorithms exploit the form of
𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2}, interpreting the problem as a change of shift from 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v}
to 𝟎0\mathbf{0}; yet at the time of writing efficient changes of shifts have
only been achieved when the target shift is larger than the origin shift
[27, Sec. 5], a fact that offers degree control for the
transformation between the two matrices. Another possibility is to compute the
so-called 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v}-Popov form 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{{P}} of 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2}, since its
transpose 𝐏𝖳superscript𝐏𝖳\mathbf{{P}}^{\mathsf{T}} is 𝟎0\mathbf{0}-reduced by definition (see
Section 2.4), and det(𝐏𝖳)=det(𝐏)superscript𝐏𝖳𝐏\det(\mathbf{{P}}^{\mathsf{T}})=\det(\mathbf{{P}}) is
det(𝐊2)subscript𝐊2\det(\mathbf{{K}}_{2}) up to a constant. However this suffers from the same issue,
as computing 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{{P}} is essentially the same as changing the shift
𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v} into the nonpositive shift −𝜹𝜹-\boldsymbol{\delta}, where 𝜹𝜹\boldsymbol{\delta} is
the list of diagonal degrees of 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2}  [ref]26. To circumvent these issues, we use the property that the transpose
𝐊2𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐊2𝖳\mathbf{{K}}_{2}^{\mathsf{T}} of a 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v}-reduced matrix is in
−𝒅𝒅-\boldsymbol{d}-reduced form where 𝒅=rdeg𝒗​(𝐊2)𝒅subscriptrdeg𝒗subscript𝐊2\boldsymbol{d}=\mathrm{rdeg}_{{\boldsymbol{v}}}(\mathbf{{K}}_{2}).
This fact naturally comes up here since det(𝐊2)=det(𝐊2𝖳)subscript𝐊2superscriptsubscript𝐊2𝖳\det(\mathbf{{K}}_{2})=\det(\mathbf{{K}}_{2}^{\mathsf{T}}), but seems otherwise rarely exploited in polynomial
matrix algorithms: in fact we did not find a previous occurrence of it apart
from related degree considerations in [56, Lem. 2.2]. Transposing the above two approaches using 𝐊2𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐊2𝖳\mathbf{{K}}_{2}^{\mathsf{T}} instead of
𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2}, we observe that computing a 𝟎0\mathbf{0}-reduced form of
𝐊2𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐊2𝖳\mathbf{{K}}_{2}^{\mathsf{T}} is a change of shift from −𝒅𝒅-\boldsymbol{d} to
𝟎0\boldsymbol{0}, and computing the −𝒅𝒅-\boldsymbol{d}-Popov form 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{{P}} of
𝐊2𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐊2𝖳\mathbf{{K}}_{2}^{\mathsf{T}} is essentially a change of shift from −𝒅𝒅-\boldsymbol{d} to
−𝜹𝜹-\boldsymbol{\delta}. In both cases the target shift is larger than the origin shift,
implying that the kernel-based change of shift of [27, Sec. 5]
involves matrices of well-controlled degrees. Still, this is not enough to make
this change of shift efficient as such, the difficulty being now that the
average row degree of 𝐊2𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐊2𝖳\mathbf{{K}}_{2}^{\mathsf{T}} may not be small: only its average
column degree, which corresponds to the average row degree of 𝐊2subscript𝐊2\mathbf{{K}}_{2}, is
controlled. Our solution uses the second approach, computing the −𝒅𝒅-\boldsymbol{d}-Popov form
𝐏𝐏\mathbf{{P}}, because it offers the a priori knowledge that the column degrees
of 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{{P}} are exactly 𝜹𝜹\boldsymbol{\delta}. We exploit this degree knowledge to
carry out partial linearization techniques, originally designed for approximant
bases  , which we extend here to kernel bases.
These techniques allow us to reduce our problem to a kernel basis computation
where the matrix entries have uniformly small degrees, implying that it can be
efficiently handled via the minimal approximant basis algorithm
PM-Basis from . The next result summarizes the new
algorithmic tool developed in Section 5 for finding
𝐏𝐏\mathbf{{P}}. Let 𝐬∈ℤm𝐬superscriptℤ𝑚\boldsymbol{s}\in\mathbb{Z}^{m}, let 𝐀∈𝕂​[x]m×m𝐀𝕂superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥𝑚𝑚\mathbf{{A}}\in\mathbb{K}[x]^{m\times m} be in
−𝐬𝐬-\boldsymbol{s}-weak Popov form, let 𝛅∈ℤ≥0m𝛅superscriptsubscriptℤabsent0𝑚\boldsymbol{\delta}\in\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}^{m} be the
−𝐬𝐬-\boldsymbol{s}-pivot degree of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}}, and assume that 𝐬≥𝛅𝐬𝛅\boldsymbol{s}\geq\boldsymbol{\delta}. There is an algorithm WeakPopovToPopov which takes as
input (𝐀,𝐬)𝐀𝐬(\mathbf{{A}},\boldsymbol{s}) and computes the −𝐬𝐬-\boldsymbol{s}-Popov form of
𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} by performing PM-Basis at order less than
|𝒔|/m+4𝒔𝑚4|\boldsymbol{s}|/m+4 on an input matrix of row dimension at
most 6​m6𝑚6m and column dimension at most 3​m3𝑚3m, multiplying the inverse of a matrix in 𝕂m×msuperscript𝕂𝑚𝑚\mathbb{K}^{m\times m} by a
matrix in 𝕂​[x]m×m𝕂superscriptdelimited-[]𝑥𝑚𝑚\mathbb{K}[x]^{m\times m} of column degree 𝜹𝜹\boldsymbol{\delta}, and performing O​(m2)𝑂superscript𝑚2\mathchoice{O\left(m^{2}\right)}{O(m^{2})}{O(m^{2})}{O(m^{2})} extra operations in 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}. Thus, computing the −𝐬𝐬-\boldsymbol{s}-Popov form of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} can be done in
O​(mω​𝖬′⁡(|𝐬|/m))𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔superscript𝖬′𝐬𝑚\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}\right)}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)})}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)})}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(|\boldsymbol{s}|/m)})} operations in
𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}. This theorem is a generalization of [42, Sec. 4] to shifted forms,
for shifts −𝒔𝒔-\boldsymbol{s} that satisfy the assumption 𝒔≥𝜹𝒔𝜹\boldsymbol{s}\geq\boldsymbol{\delta}.
Indeed, if 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{{A}} is 𝟎0\mathbf{0}-weak Popov, then one recovers
[42, Thm. 20] by taking
𝒔=(deg⁡(𝐀),…,deg⁡(𝐀))𝒔degree𝐀…degree𝐀\boldsymbol{s}=(\deg(\mathbf{{A}}),\ldots,\deg(\mathbf{{A}})) in the above theorem. For
comparison, the naive generalization of [42, Sec. 4] to shifted
forms
runs in O​(mω​𝖬′⁡(max⁡(𝒔)))𝑂superscript𝑚𝜔superscript𝖬′𝒔\mathchoice{O\left(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(\max(\boldsymbol{s})\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}\right)}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(\max(\boldsymbol{s})\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))})}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(\max(\boldsymbol{s})\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))})}{O(m^{\omega}\mathchoice{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}\!\left(\max(\boldsymbol{s})\right)}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))}{\operatorname{\mathsf{M}}^{\prime}(\max(\boldsymbol{s}))})}, which exceeds our
target complexity as soon as max⁡(𝒔)≫|𝒔|/mmuch-greater-than𝒔𝒔𝑚\max(\boldsymbol{s})\gg|\boldsymbol{s}|/m.
Hence the use of partial linearization techniques, which were not needed in the
non-shifted case featuring max⁡(𝒔)=|𝒔|/m=deg⁡(𝐀)𝒔𝒔𝑚degree𝐀\max(\boldsymbol{s})=|\boldsymbol{s}|/m=\deg(\mathbf{{A}}). As mentioned above, our Algorithm WeakPopovToPopov is based on the
computation of a kernel basis with a priori knowledge of the degree profile of
the output. This kernel problem is very close to the one handled in
[56, Sec. 4], except that in this reference one only has upper
bounds on the output degrees, implying a certain number—possibly logarithmic
in m𝑚m—of calls to PM-Basis to recover the output and its
actual degrees. In the same spirit but in the context of approximant bases, [28, Sec. 5]
uses partial linearization techniques to reduce an arbitrary input with known
output degrees to essentially one call to PM-Basis, whereas
[55, Algo. 2] assumes weaker output degree information
and makes a potentially logarithmic number of calls to PM-Basis.
